description.narrative:
Project level impact: Increased Access for SMEs/VSEs including women owned/operated SMEs/VSEs: IFC anticipates that this project will provide the Bank with an efficient risk mitigation tool that will support it to sustainably increase financing to SMEs and very small enterprises (VSEs) including women owned SMEs and VSEs. These enterprises represent over 90 percent of the total officially registered enterprises in the country and contribute about 80 percent to employment thus presenting a strategic importance for job creation and the country's economic growth but face constrained access to credit with the financing gap estimated at 21.3 percent of GDP.
Market level impact: Competitiveness: IFC expects that this project can demonstrate bankability of SMEs and VSEs on a cashflow lending basis thereby motivate other financial institutions to introduce customized products for underserved segments and come up with alternative credit scoring models. This competitive push would help scale the availability of finance for this market segment and promote financial inclusion in Myanmar where credit to the private sector, which is estimated at 25 percent of GDP, remains relatively low.

The proposed project consists of an unfunded risk sharing facility (RSF) for a portfolio of loans to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and very small enterprises (VSEs) to be originated by Yoma Bank Limited (the Bank or Yoma Bank) with 35 percent of the loans being targeted at women owned or managed SMEs or VSE. The project is part of IFCs Small Loan Guarantee Program (SLGP or Program) which is supported by the IDA18 IFC-MIGA Private Sector Window Blended Finance Facility which aims to enhance and strengthen the capacity of financial institutions (FIs) for risk taking and financing to SMEs and VSEs in IDA countries.
